Issue Title: fwatchdog with memory leak
Issue Details:
{'description': '<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->
fwatchdog with memory leak 

## Expected Behaviour
<!--- If you're describing a bug, tell us what should happen -->
<!--- If you're suggesting a change/improvement, tell us how it should work -->
I run fwatchdog by docker
set up env variable with fprocess="cat /etc/hostname"
use ab to stress test
ab -n 10000 -c 100 http://localhost:8080 (port watchdog listened to) 
after stress testing, the memory cost was stable. 

## Current Behaviour
<!--- If describing a bug, tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior -->
<!--- If suggesting a change/improvement, explain the difference from current behavior -->
The memory cost was increased and not released normally 

## Possible Solution
<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug, -->
<!--- or ideas how to implement the addition or change -->
ref to [issue](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/20989), use timer.AfterFunc to replace timer.NewTimer will solve this issue and it works fine of my service.

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
<!--- Provide a link to a live example, or an unambiguous set of steps to -->
<!--- reproduce this bug. Include code to reproduce, if relevant -->
1. run fwatchdog by docker run command: ```docker run -it --name=watchdog -p 8080:8080 --entrypoint=sh {IMAGE} ```
2. export fprocess="cat /etc/hostname"
3. fwatchdog
4. outside the docker, use ab to do benchmark ```ab -n 10000 -c 100 http://localhost:8080```
5. use ```docker stats watchdog``` could see the memory cost 

## Context
<!--- How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish? -->
<!--- Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world -->
Since memory be occupied and does not be release, other containers might be crashed due to out of memory. 

Since I got the solution, I try to make a PR now. But it takes a little time to follow the guideline.

## Your Environment
<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->
* FaaS-CLI version ( Full output from: `faas-cli version` ):

* Docker version `docker version` (e.g. Docker 17.0.05 ): 18.09.0

* Are you using Docker Swarm or Kubernetes (FaaS-netes)? Kubernetes / localhost

* Operating System and version (e.g. Linux, Windows, MacOS): Centos

* Link to your project or a code example to reproduce issue: 

* Please also follow the [troubleshooting guide](https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/guide/troubleshooting.md) and paste in any other diagnostic information you have:

', 'comments': ["Thank you very much for the PR. I'll take a look at this after the Christmas holidays.

Do you have more output data or screenshot before/after that you can share?
", '@alexellis Merry Christmas!

Here is what my test steps:

## original fwatchdog
![before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42954621/50421016-e5bbd980-0875-11e9-8895-097a0792e1b1.png)

## use timer.AfterFunc:
![after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42954621/50420992-b9a05880-0875-11e9-923f-94f7cefab110.png)

## here is the dockerfile I used:
```
FROM alpine:3.8

ADD https://github.com/openfaas/faas/releases/download/0.9.6/fwatchdog /usr/bin
# uncomment to use built fwatchdog
# COPY ./fwatchdog /usr/bin/fwatchdog
RUN chmod +x /usr/bin/fwatchdog

COPY ./fwatchdog /usr/bin/fwatchdog
# Define your binary here
ENV fprocess="/bin/cat /etc/hostname"

CMD ["fwatchdog"]
```

after docker run -p 8080:8080 watchdog:tag,
use ab command:
```
ab -n 10000 -c 100 localhost:8080/
```

Thanks for ur quickly reply!
', 'So are we looking at a difference of 3mb RAM? Alex', 'Since this is just a sample case for testing, the difference is not quite large.

In our production environment,  some function could cost upon 2G ram and reach the limitation we set for docker and it goes stable for about 35MB after the modification we made.

Or another testing way is to benchmark with ab for about 100 times, the difference might go big.

Mike

', "Can you show me how to reproduce the issue?

Can you say what you're running inside the container as your function? 

You may be best using the [of-watchdog](https://github.com/openfaas-incubator/of-watchdog) instead. The classic watchdog will spawn one process per request by design so if each process takes 10mb RAM and you only have one replica and 300 concurrent requests you'll hit that limit. ", "> Can you show me how to reproduce the issue?

It always happens after a period of time with many invocations.

> Can you say what you're running inside the container as your function?

The most used behaviors of functions are to query database. 
 
> You may be best using the [of-watchdog](https://github.com/openfaas-incubator/of-watchdog) instead. The classic watchdog will spawn one process per request by design so if each process takes 10mb RAM and you only have one replica and 300 concurrent requests you'll hit that limit.
Thanks for your information, it looks great!

Since we use faas-cli to build / deploy function, we use default templates with fwatchdog.

I'll start to use ofwatchdog but for classic fwatchdog, this is still an existed problem.

How about change the default templates to use ofwatchdog by default?

", "Let's see if we can reproduce the issue scientifically with taking a memory profile from `go test`?  https://dev.to/davidsbond/golang-debugging-memory-leaks-using-pprof-5di8

https://www.integralist.co.uk/posts/profiling-go/

What binary/language are you using for your DB queries? 

Alex

", "> Let's see if we can reproduce the issue scientifically with taking a memory profile from `go test`? https://dev.to/davidsbond/golang-debugging-memory-leaks-using-pprof-5di8

> https://www.integralist.co.uk/posts/profiling-go/

Actually this problem seems the same as this [issue](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/20989)
The reproduced steps I posted are the same mentioned in the above issue.
 
And I totally agree about memory profile testing should be included in! üëç 
 
> What binary/language are you using for your DB queries?
We use nodejs to query neo4j via a lib.
But I think we could reproduced follow the example listed  [issue](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/20989)

Many thanks for ur help and I would see if I could do something for this, too.
 
", 'Derek close: merged']}

Issue Title: remove & shutdown incorrect order (for docker swarm)
Issue Details:
{'description': 'Added functions & services may depend on the `func` stack such that it cannot be shut down without first removing those functions.

## Expected Behaviour

Following along the docs for setting up in Docker Swarm, then installing the demo funcs, the instructions at https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/guide/troubleshooting.md#stop-and-remove-openfaas should work.

## Current Behaviour

Instead, `docker stack rm func` fails with an error about a dependency.

## Possible Solution

Reverse the order of the steps. Remove services first, then remove the func stack.
', 'comments': ["Please feel free to submit a PR to the documentation site openfaas/docs. I'll remove the text in this file you linked to and think make it redirect to the docs site.

Alex", 'Turns out this is already fixed in the docs. https://docs.openfaas.com/deployment/troubleshooting/

Thanks for letting us know.

Alex']}

Issue Title: npm err! 404 not found: package from private npm registry
Issue Details:
{'description': "<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->
Hello folks!

## Expected Behaviour
Allow privates NPM Repository in faas-cli build

## Current Behaviour

We use a private npm registry for our Node.js packages.
Unfortunately we get an error message when building our OpenFaas function:

```bash
npm ERR! code E404
npm ERR! 404 Not Found: <npm-package>@^1.33.7

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     /root/.npm/_logs/2019-01-11T13_50_17_699Z-debug.log
```
```bash
Error: Cannot find module '<NPM-PACKAGE>'
 2019/01/11 13:30:08 Error reading stderr: EOF
     at Function.Module._resolveFilename (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:603:15)
     at Function.Module._resolveFilename (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:603:15)
     at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:529:25)
     at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:529:25)
     at Modu
     at Modu
 2019/01/11 13:30:01 stderr: le.require (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:657:17)
 2019/01/11 13:29:41 stderr: le.require (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:657:17)
     at require (internal/modules/cjs/helpers.js:22:18)
     at require (internal/modules/cjs/helpers.js:22:18)
     at Object.<anonymous> (/home/app/function/handler.js:2:16)
     at Object.<anonymous> (/home/app/function/handler.js:2:16)
     at Module._compile (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:721:30)
     at Object.Module._ex
 2019/01/11 13:29:41 stderr: tensions..js (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:732:10)
     at require (internal/modules/cjs/helpers.js:22:18)
     at Module.load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:620:32)
     at tryModuleLoad (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:560:12)
     at Object.<anonymous> (/home/app/function/handler.js:2:16)
     at Function.Module._load (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:552:3)
     at Module._compile (internal/modules/cjs/loader.js:721:30)
```

The problem is theoretically known, but practically somehow cannot be solved without help. :)

We get these two commands into the build process of faas-cli ?

```bash
npm set registry https://<NPM-REGISTRY>
npm adduser --registry https://<NPM-REGISTRY>
```

Unfortunately our .npmrc, which is supposed to define something like this, is not used...

## Possible Solution
<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug, -->
<!--- or ideas how to implement the addition or change -->
```bash
npm set registry https://<NPM-REGISTRY>
npm adduser --registry https://<NPM-REGISTRY>
```

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
<!--- Provide a link to a live example, or an unambiguous set of steps to -->
<!--- reproduce this bug. Include code to reproduce, if relevant -->
1. Uses a private NPM package in a Node.js app
2.
3.
4.

## Context
<!--- How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish? -->
<!--- Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world -->

## Your Environment
<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->
* FaaS-CLI version ( Full output from: `faas-cli version` ):
```bash
  ___                   _____           ____
 / _ \ _ __   ___ _ __ |  ___|_ _  __ _/ ___|
| | | | '_ \ / _ \ '_ \| |_ / _` |/ _` \___ \
| |_| | |_) |  __/ | | |  _| (_| | (_| |___) |
 \___/| .__/ \___|_| |_|_|  \__,_|\__,_|____/
      |_|

CLI:
 commit:  5b36c50280d961d3aa248bd17f901f4ef2774447
 version: 0.8.1
```
* Docker version `docker version` (e.g. Docker 17.0.05 ):
```bash
Client:
 Version:           18.09.1
 API version:       1.39

 Git commit:        4c52b90
 Built:             Wed Jan  9 19:35:31 2019

Swarm

Linux
* Link to your project or a code example to reproduce issue:
Link only on request per PM
* Please also follow the [troubleshooting guide](https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/guide/troubleshooting.md) and paste in any other diagnostic information you have:

", 'comments': ["Oky after a short think... it is quite clear!

I adjusted the dockerfile:
```bash
# COPY function node packages and install, adding this as a separate
# entry allows caching of npm install
WORKDIR /home/app/function

COPY function/.npmrc ./                         # <--------------------- :)

COPY function/*.json ./
RUN npm i || :
```
Also tested, works for me.

I'll leave it there, maybe someone else could use it.", 'You could do a PR for the node template(s) in the [templates repo](https://github.com/openfaas/templates) :smile: ', "@JohnOllhorn you'll likely want to `rm` your .npmrc once you've completed `npm i`"]}

Issue Title: investigate: nats streaming crash/lock-up
Issue Details:
{'description': '<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->

## Expected Behaviour
<!--- If you're describing a bug, tell us what should happen -->
<!--- If you're suggesting a change/improvement, tell us how it should work -->

The connection to the NATS Streaming Server in the gateway should stay up and available to serve asynchronous requests.

## Current Behaviour
<!--- If describing a bug, tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior -->
<!--- If suggesting a change/improvement, explain the difference from current behavior -->

@padiazg observed with Swarm on two occasions that NATS Streaming appeared to stop accepting new asynchronous requests. I have also noticed this with Kubernetes in OpenFaaS Cloud Community Cluster on one occasion.

## Possible Solution
<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug, -->
<!--- or ideas how to implement the addition or change -->

Tasks:
- [ ] Run NATS Streaming in HA mode or with persistence so that it can be started if an issue is detected without losing data. (https://github.com/openfaas/docs/issues/101)
- [ ] Document the three HA NATS instructions sent over from the NATS team in the docs site via https://github.com/openfaas/docs/issues/101 - in addition we need to give users clear instructions for Kubernetes + Swarm
- [ ] Investigate whether the gateway can reconnect if the NATS Streaming TCP connection is severed (this may need to be simulated by patching the gateway code) - this may be related to whether NATS is running with an in-memory filesystem or with persistence
- [ ] Add re-connect to the gateway handler.go code (publisher)
- [ ] Add re-connect handler to the nats-queue-worker code (subscriber)
- [ ] Evaluate current set of NATS Streaming Prometheus exporters and whether their metrics can be used to create alerts in AlertManager for HipChat/PagerDuty etc.

I don't believe you can restart a connection / subscription if the NATS Streaming Server is running in in-memory mode. See also: https://github.com/openfaas/nats-queue-worker/pull/33


## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
<!--- Provide a link to a live example, or an unambiguous set of steps to -->
<!--- reproduce this bug. Include code to reproduce, if relevant -->
1. Unclear

## Context
<!--- How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish? -->
<!--- Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world -->

If this crashes then manual action is required and it is currently not easy to know whether it has crashed from a dashboard/alert. This could affect people relying on NATS Streaming in production like @padiazg / Vision.

The configuration of NATS Streaming is "memory" by default:

- https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/docker-compose.yml#L79 
- https://github.com/openfaas/faas-netes/blob/master/chart/openfaas/templates/nats-dep.yaml#L36

Patricio has done some experimentation with MySQL as a backing store

## Your Environment
<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->
* FaaS-CLI version ( Full output from: `faas-cli version` ):

* Docker version `docker version` (e.g. Docker 17.0.05 ):

* Are you using Docker Swarm or Kubernetes (FaaS-netes)?

* Operating System and version (e.g. Linux, Windows, MacOS):

* Link to your project or a code example to reproduce issue:

* Please also follow the [troubleshooting guide](https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/guide/troubleshooting.md) and paste in any other diagnostic information you have:', 'comments': ['The reason NATS crashes is unknow to me, yet. But the way to reproduce it for testing purposes is killing NATS with this:
```bash
$ docker kill $(docker ps -qf "name=func_nats")
``` 
After that you will get the same results as when it crashes "in the wild"

Then you can get the stack back to work with this:
```bash
docker kill $(docker ps -qf "name=func_nats") $(docker ps -qf "name=func_queue-worker") $(docker ps -qf "name=func_gateway")
```', "I have some success, I'm testing right now reconnecting logic, but if everything will be fine, I should have PR with solution in around 2h.", 'https://github.com/openfaas/nats-queue-worker/pull/49', 'Summary: What I did so far?
- Opened [Pull Request: nats-queue-worker#49](https://github.com/openfaas/nats-queue-worker/pull/49) and addressed all comments, which resolves task: 
> Add re-connect to the gateway handler.go code (publisher)
- Opened [Pull Request: nats-queue-worker#52](https://github.com/openfaas/nats-queue-worker/pull/52) and addressed all comments, which resolves task: 
> Add re-connect handler to the nats-queue-worker code (subscriber)`

I also did a research related to prometheus exporters for NATS streaming, and till official NATS exporter wouldn't support NATS Streaming metrics (there is open PR for that: https://github.com/nats-io/prometheus-nats-exporter/pull/54) our best (and actually the only one) option is to use this exporter: https://gitlab.com/civist/nats-streaming-exporter
I couldn't find anything else, and tested that if it's exporting the metrics. I have build and pushed my own docker image and deployed it to my local swarm cluster of OpenFaaS adding to docker-compose.yml:
```
    nats-streaming-prometheus-exporter:
        image: bartsmykla/nats-streaming-exporter:0.0.1
        networks:
            - functions
        command: "/nats-streaming-exporter -nats-uri http://nats:8222"
        deploy:
            resources:
                limits:
                    memory: 125M
                reservations:
                    memory: 50M
            placement:
                constraints:
                    - 'node.platform.os == linux'
        ports:
            - 9275:9275
```
so if you want to test that exporter too, feel free to use my image: `bartsmykla/nats-streaming-exporter:0.0.1`', 'Thank you for the update Bart.

Which metrics could @padiazg make use of to alert on or observe the health of his NATS Streaming instance/cluster?', 'I think: `natsstreaming_up`, `natsstreaming_exporter_json_parse_failures`, `natsstreaming_subscriptions_pending`. Here is the full list from the exporter:
```
&Exporter{
		URI:     u,
		Timeout: timeout,
		up: prometheus.NewGauge(prometheus.GaugeOpts{
			Namespace: namespace,
			Name:      "up",
			Help:      "Was the last scrape of nats-streaming successful.",
		}),
		totalScrapes: prometheus.NewCounter(prometheus.CounterOpts{
			Namespace: namespace,
			Name:      "exporter_total_scrapes",
			Help:      "Current total nats-streaming scrapes.",
		}),
		jsonParseFailures: prometheus.NewCounter(prometheus.CounterOpts{
			Namespace: namespace,
			Name:      "exporter_json_parse_failures",
			Help:      "Number of errors while parsing JSON.",
		}),
		clientsTotal:              newDesc("clients", "Number of currently connected clients.", nil),
		channelsTotal:             newDesc("channels", "Current number of channels.", nil),
		storeMessagesTotal:        newDesc("store_messages", "Current number of messages in the store.", nil),
		storeMessagesBytes:        newDesc("store_messages_bytes", "Total size of the messages in the store.", nil),
		subscriptionsTotal:        newDesc("subscriptions", "Number of subscriptions.", []string{"channel", "client"}),
		subscriptionsPendingTotal: newDesc("subscriptions_pending", "Number of pending messages.", []string{"channel", "client"}),
		subscriptionsStalledTotal: newDesc("subscriptions_stalled", "Number of stalled subscriptions.", []string{"channel", "client"}),
		messagesTotal:             newDesc("messages", "Number of messages.", []string{"channel"}),
		messagesBytes:             newDesc("messages_bytes", "Size of the messages.", []string{"channel"}),
	}
```', 'Resolved through patches to gateway and queue-worker']}

They currently fail 100% of the time due to the Prometheus exporter integration tests due to a "closed channel" error. This happened after upgrading the Prometheus go client, but may be related to timing.

ok      github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/handlers   0.006s  coverage: 28.9% of statements
PASS
coverage: 43.9% of statements
panic: send on closed channel
goroutine 21 [running]:
github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/vendor/github.com/prometheus/client_golang/prometheus.(*metricMap).Describe(...)
    /go/src/github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/vendor/github.com/prometheus/client_golang/prometheus/vec.go:222
github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/metrics.(*Exporter).Describe(0xc420172240, 0xc420174360)
    /go/src/github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/metrics/exporter.go:45 +0xce
created by github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/metrics.Test_Describe_DescribesThePrometheusMetrics
    /go/src/github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/metrics/exporter_test.go:41 +0x17d
FAIL    github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/metrics    0.009s
ok      github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/plugin 0.010s  coverage: 81.4% of statements
?       github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/queue  [no test files]
ok      github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/requests   0.021s  coverage: 75.0% of statements
ok      github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/scaling    0.037s  coverage: 24.6% of statements
ok      github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/types  0.015s  coverage: 81.8% of statements
?       github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/version    [no test files]
The command '/bin/sh -c license-check -path ./ --verbose=false "Alex Ellis" "OpenFaaS Project" "OpenFaaS Authors" "OpenFaaS Author(s)"     && test -z "$(gofmt -l $(find . -type f -name '*.go' -not -path "./vendor/*"))"     && go test $(go list ./... | grep -v integration | grep -v /vendor/ | grep -v /template/) -cover     && CGO_ENABLED=0 GOOS=linux go build --ldflags "-s -w     -X github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/version.GitCommitSHA=${GIT_COMMIT_SHA}    -X \"github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/version.GitCommitMessage=${GIT_COMMIT_MESSAGE}\"    -X github.com/openfaas/faas/gateway/version.Version=${VERSION}"     -a -installsuffix cgo -o gateway .' returned a non-zero code: 1
make: *** [ci-armhf-build] Error 1
```

This [`defer close(ch)`](https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/b4a550327d6bddfb5a5316636e19a288345296c3/gateway/metrics/exporter_test.go#L39) is in a race with the go routine started a couple of lines further down.
You have 3 reads from the channel before the exit of the test func (which will close the channel), but in the go routine you invoke the [`Describe`](https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/b4a550327d6bddfb5a5316636e19a288345296c3/gateway/metrics/exporter.go#L39) function, that invokes 5 other `Describe`s each writing something. Thus, the last 2 channel writes are in a race with the close of the channel.

```
	e.metricOptions.ServiceMetrics.Counter.Describe(ch)
	e.metricOptions.ServiceMetrics.Histogram.Describe(ch)
```

Ways to fix this:

1. Don't close the channel.
2. Don't use a go routine.
3. Is this test doing what you need? Could be that it's outdated and in a need of rewriting.

I am surprised that it actually happens to work so often. I would expect almost 100% crash rate on a modern machine.', "I was able to workaround this by just removing `defer close(ch)`

```
diff --git a/gateway/metrics/exporter_test.go b/gateway/metrics/exporter_test.go
index 9a23a3cd..487e1565 100644
--- a/gateway/metrics/exporter_test.go
+++ b/gateway/metrics/exporter_test.go
@@ -36,7 +36,6 @@ func Test_Describe_DescribesThePrometheusMetrics(t *testing.T) {
        exporter := NewExporter(metricsOptions, nil)

        ch := make(chan *prometheus.Desc)
-       defer close(ch)

        go exporter.Describe(ch)
```

@rosti is right about the race condition, still don't know why it works on any other architecture.", 'Thank you, guys! üëç 
Tested your patch on ARMHF where it was failing on almost every build and it was working, so I created a PR based on your suggestions.', 'Derek close: fixed', 'Thank you all, @rosti üëè üëç ']}

Issue Title: performance tuning: scale_from_zero
Issue Details:
{'description': '<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->

## Expected Behaviour
<!--- If you're describing a bug, tell us what should happen -->
<!--- If you're suggesting a change/improvement, tell us how it should work -->

When a function is not in the scaling cache and concurrent requests arrive, we should lock on a Mutex so that we don't make too many calls to the back-end to query the current amount of replicas

## Current Behaviour
<!--- If describing a bug, tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior -->
<!--- If suggesting a change/improvement, explain the difference from current behavior -->

We could have a "thundering herd" situation where all 1000 +/- requests call to the back end until the cache is updated for subsequent calls.

## Possible Solution
<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug, -->
<!--- or ideas how to implement the addition or change -->

We could use a RWMutex in the scaler or in the cache for each unique function name rather than one for the whole cache.

https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/gateway/scaling/function_scaler.go#L42

https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/gateway/scaling/function_cache.go#L49', 'comments': ['Hi @alexellis

Issue Title: runc processes for functions constantly spawning
Issue Details:
{'description': 'When adding and scaling functions to an OpenFaas deployment running on Docker Swarm, runc processes are constantly exeucting for each instance of each function, and containerd-shim is consistently using 0.7% CPU per container

## Expected Behaviour
Idle functions doing no work should use little to no CPU

## Current Behaviour
Extensive CPU is being used, even when functions are idle, about 1% of the processor per instance deployed

## Possible Solution

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
1. Deploy OpenFaas via Docker Swarm
2. Deploy one or more functions to OpenFaas
3. Scale functions above 1

## Context
This issue is causing extreme performance degradation as half or more of CPU resources on each Swarm node is being consumed.by containerd-shim and runc.

## Your Environment
<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->
* FaaS-CLI version ( Full output from: `faas-cli version` ):
Not using FaaS-CLI

* Docker version `docker version` (e.g. Docker 17.0.05 ):
Docker 18.09.01

* Are you using Docker Swarm or Kubernetes (FaaS-netes)?
Swarm

* Operating System and version (e.g. Linux, Windows, MacOS):
Ubuntu 16.04

* Link to your project or a code example to reproduce issue:

* Please also follow the [troubleshooting guide](https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/guide/troubleshooting.md) and paste in any other diagnostic information you have:

Nothing in the troubleshooting guide references this problem.  The functions are executing, just with reduced speed because other resources are being consumed.  Below are example lines from an auditd log, note that runc is running on the same docker container over and over, but `docker ps` shows the container continuously running (not like it is exiting and restarting).
```
type=EXECVE msg=audit(1550080419.553:16698): argc=9 a0="runc" a1="--root" a2="/var/run/docker/runtime-runc/moby" a3="--log" a4="/run/docker/containerd/daemon/io.containerd.runtime.v1.linux/moby/d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e/log.json" a5="--log-format" a6="json" a7="state" a8="d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e"
type=CWD msg=audit(1550080419.553:16698):  cwd="/run/docker/containerd/daemon/io.containerd.runtime.v1.linux/moby/d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e"
type=EXECVE msg=audit(1550080420.089:16735): argc=9 a0="runc" a1="--root" a2="/var/run/docker/runtime-runc/moby" a3="--log" a4="/run/docker/containerd/daemon/io.containerd.runtime.v1.linux/moby/d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e/log.json" a5="--log-format" a6="json" a7="state" a8="d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e"
type=CWD msg=audit(1550080420.089:16735):  cwd="/run/docker/containerd/daemon/io.containerd.runtime.v1.linux/moby/d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e"
type=EXECVE msg=audit(1550080420.389:16771): argc=9 a0="runc" a1="--root" a2="/var/run/docker/runtime-runc/moby" a3="--log" a4="/run/docker/containerd/daemon/io.containerd.runtime.v1.linux/moby/d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e/log.json" a5="--log-format" a6="json" a7="state" a8="d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e"
type=CWD msg=audit(1550080420.389:16771):  cwd="/run/docker/containerd/daemon/io.containerd.runtime.v1.linux/moby/d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e"
type=EXECVE msg=audit(1550080422.541:16934): argc=9 a0="runc" a1="--root" a2="/var/run/docker/runtime-runc/moby" a3="--log" a4="/run/docker/containerd/daemon/io.containerd.runtime.v1.linux/moby/d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e/log.json" a5="--log-format" a6="json" a7="state" a8="d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e"
type=CWD msg=audit(1550080422.541:16934):  cwd="/run/docker/containerd/daemon/io.containerd.runtime.v1.linux/moby/d648526189b7116c6c11a8b28d450eba4acff121a6a502c84e45a4c0b26aaf9e"
```

This runs continuously until the service are scaled down to 0.
', 'comments': ["I may have figured out at least part of the issue.  I removed the HEALTHCHECK from the Dockerfile that bulds these functions (it was based on the python3 template Dockerfile), and rebuilt, and there is no longer a containerd-shim issue.  This might be my environment, apparently our rack has I/O issues, and since the healthcheck is looking for a file it may have simply been stalling too much time on I/O. The runc executions I'm guessing are how the healthchecks are run by the underlying Docker engine.  This can probably be closed.", 'Derek close']}

Issue Title: ability to specify the port in the deploy script as an argument
Issue Details:
{'description': 'The `docker-compose.yml` file has the port for the UI hardcoded, so a small change to the `deploy_stack` file and `docker-compose.yml` will allow to dynamically change it without editing any file directly.

## Expected Behaviour
An example for the suggested changes:

```
./deploy_stack.sh --port 80
```
This will allow the UI to run on port 80 instead of 8080.

Also the same would be for `deploy_stack.armhf.sh`

## Current Behaviour
Right now `deploy_stack.armhf.sh` does not accept any argument, mean while `deploy_stack.sh` accept only accepts `--no-auth` and `--help`.

## Possible Solution

1. Edit the `deploy_stack.sh` to export the environment variable 
```
export DEFAULT_PORT="8080"

while [ ! $# -eq 0 ]
do
  case "$1" in
    --port | -p)
      if [ ! -z "$2" ];
      then
        export DEFAULT_PORT=$2
      fi
      ;;    
    --no-auth | -n)
      export BASIC_AUTH="false"
      ;;
    --help | -h)
      echo "Usage: \n [default]\tdeploy the OpenFaaS core services\n --no-auth [-n]\tdisable basic authentication.\n --port [-p]\tdefine a new exposed port for the UI.\n --help\tdisplays this screen"
      exit
      ;;
  esac
  shift
done
```

2. Edit the `docker-compose` files to use the environment variable 
```
version: "3.3"
services:
    gateway:
        ports:
            - ${DEFAULT_PORT}:8080
```

3. Edit `deploy_stack.armhf.sh` and pass the arguments 
```
sh ./deploy_stack.sh $1 $2
```

## Context
This will help to change the port for the UI without any manually edit to the files, not sure if this is something people may find useful or not.

## Your Environment
* FaaS-CLI version ( Full output from: `faas-cli version` ): 
0.8.3

* Docker version `docker version` (e.g. Docker 17.0.05 ):
18.09.2

* Are you using Docker Swarm or Kubernetes (FaaS-netes)?
Swarm

* Operating System and version (e.g. Linux, Windows, MacOS):
Linux/Mac

* Link to your project or a code example to reproduce issue:
https://github.com/linuxjuggler/faas/commit/b9fc73a1e370051f1528c127be9138373e3c0ce8

* Please also follow the [troubleshooting guide](https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/guide/troubleshooting.md) and paste in any other diagnostic information you have:

', 'comments': ["Hi @linuxjuggler, I am not sure this is something we want to do.  It might suggest that the gateway is ready to be exposed on a secure port like 443 when it isn't.  In a production deployment, it is recommended that the gateway be exposed via a load balancer like nginx, which can then change the public port to be 80 as well as supporting ssl and other features required to securely expose the gateway.

Is there a specific use-case that you are trying to solve by changing the port?  

Especially for swarm, I think we would be better served by providing a walk through on customizing the deployment in the docs and making special notes about security concerns that need to be considered when making certain changes. ", 'Derek add label: wontfix
Derek add label: revist
Derek close', 'Derek remove label: wontfix Derek add label: revist Derek close', "hey @LucasRoesler , thanks for the feedback

> Is there a specific use-case that you are trying to solve by changing the port?

There is no special cause I am trying to solve here, except than manually editing the yaml files.

> it is recommended that the gateway be exposed via a load balancer like nginx

This is what I just did, thanks for the note.

> Especially for swarm, I think we would be better served by providing a walk through on customizing the deployment in the docs and making special notes about security concerns that need to be considered when making certain changes.

Totally agree with you about that, for example, the docs do not explain where the CLI should installed, which is something am still trying to figure out.

Either way, thank you very much again for the feedback üëç 

Am going to close it, so it won't provide any false assumption for anyone else.", 'Derek add label: wontfix']}

Issue Title: scaleway: swarm with multiple nodes not working as expected
Issue Details: {'description': 'Following the instructions to deploy OpenFaas on a swarm with multiple nodes returns "Error pulling metrics from provider/backend. Status code: 502" which can be read from the console tab within the browser developer tools. ## Expected Behaviour The UI should not have any problem, and the system should work. ## Current Behaviour 1. The UI returns a hidden error which can be read from the console, which indicates that the services have some problems communicating with each other. ![screen shot 2019-02-19 at 10 32 57 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27624/52997507-caaeb580-3431-11e9-80f4-8f5b8646f232.png) 2. The CLI will also throw an error when you try to log in: ``` Server returned unexpected status code: 500 - Error pulling metrics from provider/backend. Status code: 502 ``` ## Possible Solution ## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs) 1. Create a small swarm with three nodes; they are all managers ![screen shot 2019-02-19 at 9 43 19 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27624/52997680-46a8fd80-3432-11e9-9440-c68d09d20dc6.png) There is a hardware firewall between them with the following rules: * Allow all Outbound connections. * Allow Inbound ports: 22, 8080, 53, 4789, 2377, 2376, 7946 ![screen shot 2019-02-19 at 11 09 15 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27624/52999442-d2248d80-3436-11e9-95a7-7031f525aaf9.png) 2. Add a small VPS in front of them with nginx installed and configured as a load balancer (with SSL termination using CloudFlare) which will load the requests between the three managers. ``` upstream swarm { server x.x.x.x:8080; server x.x.x.x:8080; server x.x.x.x:8080; } server { listen 80; listen 443 ssl http2 default_server; server_name x.x.x.x; ssl on; ssl_certificate /etc/nginx/ssl/certificate.pem; ssl_certificate_key /etc/nginx/ssl/certificate.key; location / { proxy_pass http://swarm; } } ``` 3. Execute the deploy command `./deploy_stack.sh` and wait a few sec for all the services to run. ![screen shot 2019-02-19 at 9 44 10 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27624/52997880-cdf67100-3432-11e9-87e4-e4d104caccbd.png) 4. Check the UI and log in, everything should work great, except the error you will notice whenever you try to deploy a function, in my case I get "bad gateway" response from Cloudflare http://d.zah.me/n56q1y 5. Look at the developer console you will notice the error: ![screen shot 2019-02-19 at 10 32 57 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27624/52997507-caaeb580-3431-11e9-80f4-8f5b8646f232.png) 6. You try to login via the CLI, and you get the error: ``` Server returned unexpected status code: 500 - Error pulling metrics from provider/backend. Status code: 502 ``` 7. Looking at the gateway logs you will get the follwoing message, which indicate that the gateway cant find `faas-swarm` service: ``` func_gateway.1.sb0elhkc4kdw@master | 2019/02/19 06:39:59 Forwarded [GET] to /system/functions - [502] - 0.009134 seconds func_gateway.1.sb0elhkc4kdw@master | 2019/02/19 06:40:01 Get http://faas-swarm:8080/system/functions: dial tcp: lookup faas-swarm on 127.0.0.11:53: no such host func_gateway.1.sb0elhkc4kdw@master | 2019/02/19 06:40:03 error with upstream request to: /system/functions, Get http://faas-swarm:8080/system/functions: dial tcp: lookup faas-swarm on 127.0.0.11:53: no such host ``` 8. Running the command `docker stack ps func` you will notice that `faas-swarm` and `gateway` are not on the same node ![screen shot 2019-02-19 at 9 39 35 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27624/52998214-c8e5f180-3433-11e9-871a-f3a89b4d84db.png) `faas-swarm` on master 2, meanwhile `gateway` on master 1. **PS**: One thing I might need to test more further is having a swarm from one manager and two workers. ## Context Am sure this is not how the system should work if I switch all of this to only a swarm from one node it will work without any problem since they will all be on the same node. The [lab1](https://github.com/openfaas/workshop/blob/master/lab1.md) assumes that you are going to use a swarm from one node. ## Your Environment * FaaS-CLI version ( Full output from: `faas-cli version` ): commit: a141dedf94ffeed84412365fd591bdc8999c5a1b version: 0.8.3 * Docker version `docker version` (e.g. Docker 17.0.05 ): ```Client: Version: 18.09.2 API version: 1.39 Go version: go1.10.6 Git commit: 6247962 Built: Sun Feb 10 04:13:50 2019 OS/Arch: linux/amd64 Experimental: false Server: Docker Engine - Community Engine: Version: 18.09.2 API version: 1.39 (minimum version 1.12) Go version: go1.10.6 Git commit: 6247962 Built: Sun Feb 10 03:42:13 2019 OS/Arch: linux/amd64 Experimental: false ``` * Are you using Docker Swarm or Kubernetes (FaaS-netes)? Docker Swarm * Operating System and version (e.g. Linux, Windows, MacOS): Linux Ubuntu Xenial (16.04 LTS) (GNU/Linux 4.4.0-142-generic x86_64), on a Scaleway VPS (https://github.com/scaleway/image-ubuntu), I am using a small version they have built specifically for small servers * Please also follow the [troubleshooting guide](https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/guide/troubleshooting.md) and paste in any other diagnostic information you have: Steps to Reproduce section should have all the logs I've collected ', 'comments': ['Hi, Thanks for your interest in OpenFaaS. I am unaware of any issues with Swarm or multiple node support. What I've done is to spend some time to set up a 3-node cluster on Packet.net and take some screenshots to demonstrate that this worked without error: Here's my thoughts: I can't reproduce any multi-node issue in Swarm with OpenFaaS, so it points to your environment: Could I make a suggestion? Perhaps using DigitalOcean's Kubernetes service would work out better for you? This is a cheap and effective service and their offering is reliable. What you may have is an issue with your cloud provider (Scaleway's kernel image). What Image did you use there? They have a "Docker" image which may work better. Your Nginx configuration could also be part of the problem, or the firewall rules you have picked. I'm going to close this issue since it is not a problem with OpenFaaS, however if you can how that this issue is a problem with OpenFaaS we'll prioritise it and fix it. * Try DigitalOcean https://www.openfaas.com/blog/digitalocean-one-click/ https://www.openfaas.com/blog/deploy-digitalocean-ansible/ https://blog.alexellis.io/digitalocean-kubernetes-engine/ I can suggest other clouds, but if you're using Scaleway, I assume that economy is important? * Use Scaleway support * Use the Docker Forum for support https://forums.docker.com Good luck Alex', "Never mind guys, thanks for all the help. I'll go over all the notes that you have mentioned and see what is the issue. Thanks again, Have a nice day", "I found the issue. The Firewall should have the port `53` open for both TCP/UDP ![screen shot 2019-02-19 at 12 17 07 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27624/53003638-7959f280-3440-11e9-99b8-1a372e0752fd.png) ![screen_shot_2019-02-19_at_12_22_26_pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27624/53003944-29c7f680-3441-11e9-8c08-bb34383c1c1f.png) Which is something the docs didn't mention, the only thing it has related to [swarm ports](https://docs.openfaas.com/deployment/docker-swarm/#12-join-any-workers-you-need), and I suggest that the docs say more information about the required ports for the system to work. Sorry, @alexellis if I was rude to you or anyone. Have a nice day.", 'Great to see that you figured it out üëç The OpenFaaS docs link to the Swarm documentation that details the ports needed etc. Maybe this will help another user in the future. Alex', 'Derek lock: resolved']}

Issue Title: chunked response from function is blocked
Issue Details:
{'description': 'Dear maintainers,

I created an issue to of-watchdog repository (https://github.com/openfaas-incubator/of-watchdog/issues/49).
And I think openfaas itself also has similar issues.

----


I wrote my template that is similar to https://github.com/openfaas-incubator/python-flask-template/tree/master/template/python3-flask.

The different from the original is that my template uses stream response (or, chunked response) as follows.

```py
@app.route("/", defaults={"path": ""}, methods=["POST", "GET"])
@app.route("/<path:path>", methods=["POST", "GET"])
def main_route(path):
    ...
    def gen():
        yield "1"
        time.sleep(1)
        yield "2"
        time.sleep(1)
        yield "3"

    return Response(gen())
```

When I invoke a function from the template, the function does not return response chunk by chunk.
It blocks 3 seconds, and then, returns whole the response (1, 2 and 3) all at once.

## Expected Behaviour
Function returns response chunk by chunk.

## Current Behaviour
Function blocks 3 seconds, and then, returns whole the response all at once.

## Possible Solution
The following code may block until whole the response returned.

https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/04d240aac26acdaf49863dbab768b4f5cb311d84/gateway/handlers/forwarding_proxy.go#L130

And I found a hint to solve this issue in httputil package's ReverseProxy.copyBuffer method.

https://golang.org/src/net/http/httputil/reverseproxy.go#L335

copyBuffer method reads response little by little and writes to maxLatencyWriter

https://golang.org/src/net/http/httputil/reverseproxy.go#L366

and maxLatencyWriter flushes periodically.

https://golang.org/src/net/http/httputil/reverseproxy.go#L418

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
1. fetch this template https://github.com/openfaas-incubator/python-flask-template/tree/master/template/python3-flask
2. edit the template as described above
3. create new function from the template
4. build, push, deploy and invoke the function

## Your Environment
Docker version 18.09.1, build 4c52b90
Docker swarm
Linux (vagrant, vm.box = "bento/centos-7.4")

Thank you.', 'comments': ["Hi,

Thanks for your interest in OpenFaaS.

I see that returning chunked-encoding is actually supported and not blocked, it just gets buffered before being returned to you.

> Function blocks 3 seconds, and then, returns whole the response all at once.

In this example your client should be blocked for two seconds, not 3 given you have `sleep(1)` only twice.

The example given is a contrived example. Can you explain your business use-case which specifically needs a chunked-encoding to stream to the caller? Just to be up-front about this, it's unlikely to change, but I'd be curious to know more.

If you have long-running functions my advice would be to use the asynchronous processing in OpenFaaS. 

https://docs.openfaas.com/deployment/troubleshooting/#asynchronous-functions

I'll close the issue, but please keep commenting.

Alex"]}

Issue Title: watchdog: content-length environment variable not consistent naming
Issue Details:
{'description': '## Expected Behaviour
Content-Length header value should be exported as an environment variable `Http_Content_Length`

## Current Behaviour
Content-Length header value should be exported as an environment variable `Http_ContentLength`. This is not consistent with other http headers, where the convention is to use the header name with `-` replaced with `_`. See:

```
Http_Accept=application/json, text/plain, */*
Http_Cookie=arp_scroll_position=287
Http_Referer=http://localhost:8080/ui/
Http_Accept_Language=en-GB,en;q=0.9
Http_Content_Type=text/plain
Http_Origin=http://localhost:8080
Http_X_Forwarded_Host=localhost:8080
Http_Connection=keep-alive
Http_User_Agent=Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_3) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/72.0.3626.119 Safari/537.36
Http_Accept_Encoding=gzip, deflate, br
Http_X_Call_Id=21a000bd-8c96-4925-bb4d-038469ab253c
Http_X_Forwarded_For=10.255.0.2:56402
Http_X_Start_Time=1552672677370023500
Http_Method=POST
Http_ContentLength=-1
Http_Path=/
Http_Host=env:8080
```


## Possible Solution
To enable backwards compatibility keep the existing `Http_ContentLength` environment variable.

Add new `Http_Content_Length` environment variable

## Todo

Decide how to depreciate `Http_ContentLength` ?

', 'comments': ["SGTM.

For the deprecation publish both names and in the future we'll deprecate the older one. 

Do you have bandwidth for this and if not could you find someone? 

* https://github.com/openfaas/faas/tree/master/watchdog
* https://github.com/openfaas-incubator/of-watchdog

Alex", "@alexellis it's on my list", "@alexellis @ewilde of-watchdog already has `Http_Content_Length`: https://github.com/matipan/of-watchdog/blob/master/main.go#L270-L273 
So we don't need to change anything there. I validated deploying a new function that prints the contents of `Http_Content_Length` and it does have the correct value."]}

Issue Title: auto-scale doesn't work
Issue Details:
{'description': "<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->

    curl -X POST http://domain.com:port/async-function/nodeinfo -d ''
```
my k8s will start a pod, so that the function will work.

<!--- If describing a bug, tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior -->
<!--- If suggesting a change/improvement, explain the difference from current behavior -->

```
    curl -X POST http://domain.com:port/async-function/nodeinfo -d ''
```
The pod doesn't scale, and the queue worker get a i/o timeout.


but when I use
```
    curl -X POST http://domain.com:port/function/nodeinfo -d ''
```

## Possible Solution

I think this is a bug....(sorry...)

I can use any function before check their available replica. But 

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
<!--- Provide a link to a live example, or an unambiguous set of steps to -->
<!--- reproduce this bug. Include code to reproduce, if relevant -->
1. open scale from zero.deploy openfaas-idler 
2. deploy sample function nodeinfo ( output CPU hostname information )
3. 
```
    curl -X POST http://domain.com:port/async-function/nodeinfo -d ''
```

## Context
<!--- How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish? -->
<!--- Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world -->

async-invoke:
when pod was ` pod>1 `, the auto-scale works. but when `pod=0` auto-scale doesn't work.
sync-invoker is OK

## Your Environment
<!--- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->
* FaaS-CLI version ( Full output from: `faas-cli version` ):

* Docker version `docker version` (e.g. Docker 17.0.05 ):

* Are you using Docker Swarm or Kubernetes (FaaS-netes)?
Kubernetes

Linux

* Please also follow the [troubleshooting guide](https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/guide/troubleshooting.md) and paste in any other diagnostic information you have:

", 'comments': ["I'll look into this issue", 'Scale from zero is not supported for asynchronous invocations of functions at present and issues exist to track that already.

This feature was logged 8 months ago but nobody has committed to working on it. See below:

https://github.com/openfaas/nats-queue-worker/issues/32

If you expect to invoke functions asynchronously then I would suggest that you do not mark them as valid for scaling to zero.

Feel free to +1 the issue linked. 

Alex']}

Issue Title: revisiting the discussion on mounting volumes in functions
Issue Details:
{'description': 'Hello,
The discussion in this thread: https://github.com/openfaas/faas/issues/320 is pretty interesting, but I've been pondering some of the arguments.

Now I can generally sympathise with the take from @alexellis and others that some use cases for this might be considered "an anti-pattern for functions which are short-lived and stateless. This will encourage stateful behavior and assumptions." however I do also think that's slightly presumptuous, because not all volumes are the same and not all use cases necessarily have volumes mounted read/write

A scenario that I am thinking of might include a function that makes use of a machine learning model. Now in this case the function might of itself have short lived and stateless behaviour but that behaviour could depend upon a potentially very large, perhaps multi GB, model.

Now clearly one could argue that an approach might be to build the function containing said model, however that then results in a very large container which **might** be OK if the lifecycles of the model and function are intrinsically linked, but I rather suspect that there are advantages to them being rather more decoupled in many circumstances and certainly in my organisation the lifecycles of model creation and usage would seem to be somewhat orthogonal which points to a number of advantages in being able to create a model as a volume and have a function mount the volume.

So, TBH, I think that there is more nuance to this discussion than simply volume mounts = stateful = antipattern. I think that there are a number of equally good arguments for keeping containers as small as possible - these things are rarely totally black or white and I think that the danger of making a framework overly opinionated one way or the other risks making it unnecessarily unsuitable for a number of use cases.

None of this is to say that I disagree with the principals that have been espoused and I'm certainly a big fan of the 12FA and serverless manifestos, I'm just suggesting that when you build a compelling framework you'll inevitably find stakeholders trying to make creative use of it and it's worth bearing that in mind.', 'comments': ['Duplicate of #320', "Thanks for your thoughts @fadams 

What is your specific business use-case? Can you run us through it?

I'm going to close the issue since we already have one tracking it and don't have persistent volumes / claims on the roadmap. ", "I thought that I'd explained the specific use-case above namely that functions based on machine learning can often depend on extremely large models of multi-giga byte size and that it is pretty much just as much of an anti-pattern to be pushing around multi-GB containers as it is mounting volumes and moreover it is very often the case that the lifecycles of model creation and model usage in ML are quite different so having the model stored as a read only volume mounted to a relatively small container tends to make logical sense.

This does **not** equate to the function in question necessarily having stateful behaviour.

Given that functions in OpenFaaS seem to be visible as K8s pods I'd have assumed that it wouldn't be a *technically* huge issue and not including them seems to be more of a philosophical issue.

That's OK, but I think that there are definitely a number of legitimate use-cases in this space that I'd say merit some reasonable discussion and even if its not in the roadmap. I think discussion around this is useful too because other people might may well be facing similar situations and discussion might help identify potential alternative approaches.

Like some of the contributors in the original thread I'm spending an undue amount of time and energy trying to convince my management that a serverless architecture is the way we should be going and it makes life a whole lot easier when one is able to field compelling responses to this type of question.

Another observation that I'd make is that whilst efficiency is fine you do seem to be awfully quick at closing issues/questions. TBH I very much doubt that too many people end up engaging in discussions marked as closed (I only stumbled across https://github.com/openfaas/faas/issues/320 serendipitously by accident whilst searching for something else). I'd say that an open source project is as much about fostering a community as it is about the code and closing off issues this quickly where a number of stakeholders have expressed legitimate interest in the topic comes across as a bit, well, dismissive really."]}

Issue Title: mqtt connector
Issue Details:
{'description': "I'm looking to run OpenFaaS and trigger functions from MQTT topics (they already exist, so the name of the topics has to be completely custom). I've been doing a lot of searches and I can't find much details on any MQTT connectors for OpenFaas. MQTT is displayed in one picture in the docs, but the only relevant information I can find is to set up a connector with Kafka, but that's rather overkill for my use case, I'm looking for a simple setup that I can run on Raspberry Pi.

**So my question is, how would I trigger a function from a MQTT topic?**
", 'comments': ['Hi @HakanL,

The connectors that are available from the project and community are displayed in the docs under "triggers" https://docs.openfaas.com/reference/triggers/

You'll also see a link for how to build an MQTT connector using the OpenFaaS connector-sdk. I would suggest you either use this to build your own or reach out to OpenFaaS Ltd if you'd like to comission the work via alex@openfaas.com

Does this answer the question?

Alex

', 'Derek add label: support', 'Derek add label: question', "Yea that's the information I found too, but since I saw MQTT in the picture there I was surprised that nobody had implemented a connector like that before, it seems like it would be a very common use case (I may be wrong on that of course), thinking maybe I overlooked or misunderstood something. I'll look at the Connector SDK, thanks for pointing me in the right direction and I think we can close this question/issue.", 'Let me know how you want to proceed. ', "I'll close the question since it's been answered now. Feel free to keep commenting or join Slack to chat to the community. ", 'You may find this interesting which is an MQTT broker written in Python:

https://github.com/alexellis/iot-sensors-mqtt-openfaas/blob/master/mqtt-broker/app.py', "@HakanL I'm also interested in an MQTT connector, and have found https://github.com/eclipse/paho.mqtt.rust which is MQTT->Redis", "@robmarkcole I wrote a connector for MQTT, but there's more work needed to update the readme, etc before it's ready to be put up here.", '@HakanL waiting for your connector, not ready yet? :(', 'If anyone has a pressing business need for this please do get in touch with me so see how we can help. ', '> @HakanL waiting for your connector, not ready yet? :(

I started building it, but the business need changed so I never finished, sorry :(', 'I have created a simple MQTT connector: [f43i4n/faas-mqtt-connector](https://github.com/f43i4n/faas-mqtt-connector)
It currently only has basic MQTT functionality and few configuration options, but it may fulfil your needs or you could create a PR to improve the connector.', "Here's our official MQTT connector, it was required for a commercial project and so it gave a good reason to build it for the community.

https://github.com/openfaas-incubator/mqtt-connector

Connecting drone event data to Postgres / Mapbox:

https://github.com/packet-labs/iot", "@f43i4n is there anything in your connector that you'd like to contribute back? Can our new connector do everything you needed? cc @HakanL @amirmhp98 @robmarkcole", "I'm no longer working on the project that needed this, but based on a quick glance it seems what you've released should work. Thanks!"]}

Issue Details:

## Expected Behaviour
The output of the script will be shown one by one and will not stop until it comes to 1000.


## Current Behaviour
The output was stop at a certain number when the function try to scale maked as Not Ready for several second and then continued to run.

## Possible Solution
Because the problem is that I only use one node to build up OpenFass, but when I add another nodes in the swarm, it seems that the master doesn't distribute the task to the other work nodes.


## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)

my code of function
```python
import json
import random

def handle(req):
    r = req

    return r

```
2. run the script
```shell
for i in {0..1000};
do

done;
```

Issue Title: swagger/openapi: syntax error in /system/logs and logentry definition
Issue Details:
{'description': "<!-- Due dilligence -->

## My actions before raising this issue
- [x] Followed the [troubleshooting guide](https://docs.openfaas.com/deployment/troubleshooting/)
- [x] Read/searched [the docs](https://docs.openfaas.com/)
- [x] Searched [past issues](/issues)

<!--- Provide a general summary of the issue in the Title above -->

## Expected Behaviour
<!--- If you're describing a bug, tell us what should happen -->
<!--- If you're suggesting a change/improvement, tell us how it should work -->

When following the instructions as described in https://github.com/openfaas/faas/tree/master/api-docs, the Swagger Editor should render the API documentation without errors

## Current Behaviour
<!--- If describing a bug, tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior -->
<!--- If suggesting a change/improvement, explain the difference from current behavior -->

Swagger editor shows this message:

![swagger](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/759624/63323924-331a1900-c327-11e9-843d-144daae7a34c.png)

## Possible Solution
<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug, -->
<!--- or ideas how to implement the addition or change -->

Fix the indentation in the description of the `/system/logs` endpoint and rename `property` to `properties` in the `LogEntry` definition

## Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)
<!--- Provide a link to a live example, or an unambiguous set of steps to -->
<!--- reproduce this bug. Include code to reproduce, if relevant -->
1. Head over to the [Swagger editor](editor.swagger.io)
2. Now click File -> Import URL
3. Type in https://raw.githubusercontent.com/openfaas/faas/master/api-docs/swagger.yml and click OK

## Additional ideas of improvement

- I'd suggest adding a tool such as [spectral](https://github.com/stoplightio/spectral) to the CI build pipeline to lint the api spec
- I see in #1246 that you do not plan to use the spec for generating SDKs but if other people want to do it, it would make sense to handle the warnings (such as missing `operationId`) as well.
", 'comments': ["Hi @nlochschmidt 

Thank you for finding this. I can't think how we let this error slip through, but I've notified the author based upon `git blame`. Going forward, this error-checking would reduce the risk of errors being introduced again.

spectral appears to be a JavaScript tool and I would rather not having to mandate Node.js for development of OpenFaaS, so can we run it in a Docker container perhaps?

If you are happy to fix the error in the Swagger I will be standing by to merge it.

Thank you again for picking this up.

Alex", 'Will do. 

Regarding the linter: It's quite easy to run the linter in docker as there is an official docker image from Stoplight. Basically it would work like this:

```sh
docker run -it --rm -v "$APIDOC_DIR":"$APIDOC_DIR" stoplight/spectral lint "$APIDOC_DIR/swagger.yml"
```

The return code will be non-zero in case of errors, I haven't tried yet if warnings lead to non-zero exit code as well, but would hope not.', 'As you can see I have opened an MR for the api docs. I would open a second one for the linter if I get around to understand how the `ci.sh` works :wink:', 'I had a look into the OpenAPI linter "spectral" but it seems like warnings cause the same non-zero exit code (1) as errors and there is an open issue for this in spectral: https://github.com/stoplightio/spectral/issues/368

Two options:
1.) fix all the warnings (see [spectral-warnings.txt](https://github.com/openfaas/faas/files/3525732/spectral-warnings.txt))
2.) exclude all those rulesets from the linter that cause warnings

', '@nichochen can this be closed now?', 'The issue has been resolved.']}

Issue Title: multi-arch image script is incorrectly detecting images on docker hub
Issue Details:
{'description': 'Multi-arch image script is incorrectly detecting images on Docker Hub

## Expected Behaviour
<!--- If you're describing a bug, tell us what should happen -->
<!--- If you're suggesting a change/improvement, tell us how it should work -->

The script on this line, should determine whether an image exists on the Docker Hub before attempting to build.

https://github.com/openfaas/faas/blob/master/contrib/publish-arm.sh#L51

## Current Behaviour
<!--- If describing a bug, tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior -->
<!--- If suggesting a change/improvement, explain the difference from current behavior -->

It returns "true" as in the image exists even for those which do not.


## Possible Solution
<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug, -->
<!--- or ideas how to implement the addition or change -->

See if the API changed, try the line in isolation, fix and then send a PR. ', 'comments': ['I can take a look at this', 'Testing the script needs to be done on Linux or RPi, perhaps `docker run -ti ubuntu` would be suitable for debugging?

Perhaps the issue is that `Not found` is now lowercase in the Docker HUB API? They recently pushed changes to enable robot accounts.

For a tag that doesn't exist: 0.19.0

```
export TAG=0.19.0
export ARM_VERSION=armhf
TAG_PRESENT=$(curl -s "https://hub.docker.com/v2/repositories/${IMAGE}/tags/${TAG}-${ARM_VERSION}/" | grep -Po '"detail": *"[^"]*"' | grep -o 'Not found')
echo $TAG_PRESENT


export TAG=0.19.0
export ARM_VERSION=armhf
TAG_PRESENT=$(curl -s "https://hub.docker.com/v2/repositories/${IMAGE}/tags/${TAG}-${ARM_VERSION}/" | grep -o 'not found')
echo $TAG_PRESENT
not found
```

For a tag that does from: https://hub.docker.com/r/openfaas/gateway/tags

I am also seeing 2x `//` symbols, which seems to be causing an issue

```
export TAG=0.17.0
export ARM_VERSION=armhf
TAG_PRESENT=$(curl -s "https://hub.docker.com/v2/repositories/${IMAGE}/tags/${TAG}-${ARM_VERSION}/" | grep -o 'not found')
echo $TAG_PRESENT
not found
echo "https://hub.docker.com/v2/repositories/${IMAGE}tags/${TAG}-${ARM_VERSION}/" 
https://hub.docker.com/v2/repositories//tags/0.17.0-armhf/
```

Removing that slash:

```
TAG_PRESENT=$(curl -s "https://hub.docker.com/v2/repositories/${IMAGE}tags/${TAG}-${ARM_VERSION}/" | grep -o 'not found')
echo $TAG_PRESENT
not found
echo "https://hub.docker.com/v2/repositories/${IMAGE}tags/${TAG}-${ARM_VERSION}/" 
https://hub.docker.com/v2/repositories/tags/0.17.0-armhf/

```', "Thanks @Waterdrips, I'll leave it with you.", 'In the future, please add to your commit message or PR the text "Closes: #X"']}

Issue Title: all invoking are concentrated on in one replica
Issue Details:
{'description': "<!-- Due dilligence -->
When I tested the default auto-scaling feature, I found that even though the number of replicas increased, all invoking were executed in one replica.

Issue Title: open faas using google container registry
Issue Details:
{'description': 'Hi, 
are we able to use Google Container Registry instead of Docker Hub for the registry? 

Regards, 
Ming', 'comments': ['yes, we do this regularly at my work. 

If your registry is public, then it will work without any additional configuration.  

If your registry is not public, then if you are using kubernetes, you need to add a ImagePullSecret to your cluster and use that with your functions _or_ add it to the ServiceAccount used by OpenFaaS.  You can find some documentation about this process in the docs here https://docs.openfaas.com/deployment/kubernetes/#use-a-private-registry-with-kubernetes', "thanks for the quick response. 
Alright, will give that a try and see if there's any issues. 
", '/msg: slack', '--
Join Slack to connect with the community
https://docs.openfaas.com/community
', 'Please use Slack for technical support going forward. Thank you for your interest in the project. ']}

Issue Title: simple "hello world" project: "exec format error" - node + php [armhf]
Issue Details:

<!--- If you're suggesting a change/improvement, tell us how it should work -->

It should be possible to deploy custom functions to an OpenFaas running on an armhf like Raspberry PI 4.

## Current Behaviour
<!--- If describing a bug, tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior -->
<!--- If suggesting a change/improvement, explain the difference from current behavior -->

OpenFaas is running. Public functions (e.g. certinfo) do work.
Deploying custom functions with `php7` or `node-armhf` doesnt work.

    pi@openfaas-01:~ $ sudo kubectl logs deploy/hello-node-world -n openfaas-fn
    standard_init_linux.go:211: exec user process caused "exec format error"

<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug, -->
<!--- or ideas how to implement the addition or change -->

<!--- Provide a link to a live example, or an unambiguous set of steps to -->
<!--- reproduce this bug. Include code to reproduce, if relevant -->

2. Create a custom function
3. Build + Push to private registry
4. Add registry credentials to `/var/lib/rancher/k3s/agent/etc/containerd/config.toml.tmpl`
5. Add the registry as "unsafe" (http endpoint) to `/var/lib/rancher/k3s/agent/etc/containerd/config.toml.tmpl` (not sure if relevant)
